column2: The new EU Strategy ‘European Climate Law’ and the ‘Fit for 55’ package
column5: The implementation of the European Climate Law and the 'Fit for 55' package is likely to have a positive impact on the circular economy target of halving the amount of residual municipal waste by 2030, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: 2040 target under discussion
column5: The discussion of a 2040 target under the European Climate Law may have a positive impact on the target of diversifying the Union's imports of strategic raw materials, as it encourages the development of sustainable and resilient supply chains.

column2: Reduce of 55% GHG emissions compared to 1990 levels (2040 target under discussion)
column5: The reduction of greenhouse gas emissions by 55% compared to 1990 levels may have a positive impact on the target of manufacturing capacity in the Union for strategic net-zero technologies, as it promotes the development of clean and sustainable technologies.

column2: Achieve a climate-resilient society status, fully adapted to the unavoidable impacts of climate change
column5: The achievement of a climate-resilient society status may have a positive impact on the target of targeted revision of the Critical Raw Materials Act, as it encourages the development of sustainable and resilient supply chains.

column2: CBAM
column5: The implementation of the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism (CBAM) may have a positive impact on the target of recycled content in packaging, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Recast
column5: The recast of EU legislation may have a positive impact on the target of recycling of plastic in packaging, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Reduce methane emissions of 35% if compared to 2005 levels
column5: The reduction of methane emissions may have a positive impact on the target of recycled content in industrial batteries, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Reach energy neutrality in the wastewater treatment sector by 2040
column5: The achievement of energy neutrality in the wastewater treatment sector may have a positive impact on the target of reducing packaging waste, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: The contribution of the sectors covered by the EU ETS with respect to the EU Climate ambition should be of -62 % compared to 2005 (increasing the linear emissions reduction factor from 2.2 % per year up to 4.4 %)
column5: The increase in the linear emissions reduction factor may have a negative impact on the target of manufacturing capacity in the Union for strategic net-zero technologies, as it may lead to increased costs and reduced competitiveness.

column2: The total quantity of allowances for the new emissions trading system should follow a linear trajectory to reach the emission reduction target for 2030, taking into account the cost-efficient contribution of the buildings and road transport sectors of 43 % emission reductions by 2030 compared to 2005 and of the additional sectors, a combined cost-efficient contribution of 42 % emission reductions by 2030 compared to 2005.
column5: The implementation of the new emissions trading system may have a negative impact on the target of targeted revision of the Critical Raw Materials Act, as it may lead to increased costs and reduced competitiveness.

column2: Upgrade national targets in line with an EU-wide reduction of 40% in the ESR sectors compared to 2005
column5: The upgrade of national targets may have a positive impact on the target of diversifying the Union's imports of strategic raw materials, as it encourages the development of sustainable and resilient supply chains.

column2: Achieve an EU net greenhouse gas removal of 310 million tonnes CO2 equivalent per year for the land use, land use change and forestry (LULUCF) sector by 2030
column5: The achievement of an EU net greenhouse gas removal may have a positive impact on the target of collecting waste portable batteries, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: For the period from 2021 to 2025, each Member State shall ensure that greenhouse gas emissions from the sector do not exceed greenhouse gas removals, calculated as the sum of total emissions and total removals on its territory in all of the land accounting categories (no debit rule).
column5: The implementation of the no debit rule may have a positive impact on the target of preparing for re-use and recycling of municipal waste, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Each Member State shall ensure that the annual sum of its greenhouse gas emissions and removals on its territory and in all of the land reporting categories, in each year in the period from 2026 to 2030, does not exceed the limit established by a linear trajectory, ending in 2030 on the target set out for that Member State (no debit rule).
column5: The implementation of the no debit rule may have a positive impact on the target of recovery of materials from waste, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Reduce buildings’ greenhouse gas emissions by 60%, compared to 2015 levels, by 2030
column5: The reduction of buildings' greenhouse gas emissions may have a negative impact on the target of targeted revision of the Critical Raw Materials Act, as it may lead to increased costs and reduced competitiveness.

column2: To achieve 55% reduction of GHG emission by 2030, methane emissions related to energy production and consumption should be reduced by 58% compared to the level in 2020
column5: The reduction of methane emissions may have a positive impact on the target of recycled content in industrial batteries, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: Halve the amount of residual (non-recycled) municipal waste by 2030
column5: The reduction of residual municipal waste may have a positive impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Reduce landfill to a maximum of 10% of municipal waste
column5: The reduction of landfill may have a positive impact on the target of reaching energy neutrality in the wastewater treatment sector, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Double its circular material use rate in the coming decade
column5: The increase in circular material use rate may have a positive impact on the target of achieving a climate-resilient society status, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: By 2030, manufacturing capacity in the Union of the strategic net-zero technologies listed in the Annex approaches or reaches a benchmark of at least 40% of the Union’s annual deployment needs for the corresponding technologies necessary to achieve the Union’s 2030 climate and energy targets
column5: The increase in manufacturing capacity may have a negative impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, as it may lead to increased energy consumption and emissions.

column2: By 2030, producers will have responsibility for their products along the value chain, including when they become waste. The circular textiles ecosystem is thriving, driven by sufficient capacities for innovative fibre-to-fibre recycling, while the incineration and landfilling of textiles is reduced to the minimum.
column5: The development of a circular textiles ecosystem may have a positive impact on the target of reducing buildings' greenhouse gas emissions, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: By 2030, the recycling rate for municipal waste will be at least 65%
column5: The increase in recycling rate may have a positive impact on the target of achieving a no debit rule, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: The EU will be a front-runner in the global transition to a circular economy, with a thriving market for circular products and services, and a strong and competitive circular industry.
column5: The development of a circular economy may have a negative impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the EU ETS, as it may lead to increased energy consumption and emissions.

column2: Union's access to a secure and sustainable supply of critical raw materials by ensuring that the Union's extraction capacity is able to extract the ores, minerals or concentrates needed to produce at least 10% of the Union's annual consumption of strategic raw materials, to the extent that the Union’s reserves allow for this
column5: The increase in extraction capacity may have a positive impact on the target of upgrading national targets, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces dependence on imports.

column2: Union's access to a secure and sustainable supply of critical raw materials by ensuring that the Union's processing capacity, including for all intermediate processing steps, is able to produce at least 40% of the Union's annual consumption of strategic raw materials
column5: The increase in processing capacity may have a positive impact on the target of achieving an EU net greenhouse gas removal, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Diversify the Union's imports of strategic raw materials with a view to ensuring that, by 2030, the Union's annual consumption of each strategic raw material at any relevant stage of processing can rely on imports from several third countries or from overseas countries or territories (OCTs) and that no third country accounts for more than 65% of the Union's annual consumption of such a strategic raw material
column5: The diversification of imports may have a positive impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the LULUCF sector, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces dependence on imports.

column2: Diversify the Union's imports of strategic raw materials with a view to ensure that the Union's recycling capacity, including for all intermediate recycling steps, is able to produce at least 25% of the Union's annual consumption of strategic raw materials and that no third country accounts for more than 65% of the Union's annual consumption of such a strategic raw material
column5: The increase in recycling capacity may have a positive impact on the target of reducing methane emissions, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: By 2030, manufacturing capacity in the Union of the strategic net-zero technologies listed in the Annex approaches or reaches a benchmark of at least 40% of the Union’s annual deployment needs for the corresponding technologies necessary to achieve the Union’s 2030 climate and energy targets
column5: The increase in manufacturing capacity may have a negative impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, as it may lead to increased energy consumption and emissions.

column2: nan
column5: The development of new technologies may have a positive impact on the target of implementing the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces greenhouse gas emissions.

column2: nan
column5: The development of new technologies may have a negative impact on the target of recasting EU legislation, as it may lead to increased costs and reduced competitiveness.

column2: Producers of portable batteries or, where appointed in accordance with Article 57(1), producer responsibility organisations, shall ensure that all waste portable batteries, Light Means of Transport (LMT) batteries and SLI batteries, regardless of their nature, chemical composition, condition, brand or origin, are collected separately in the territory of a Member State where they make these batteries available on the market for the first time.
column5: The collection of waste batteries may have a positive impact on the target of reducing methane emissions, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Producers of portable batteries or producer responsibility organisations, shall attain, and maintain durably, at least the following collection targets for waste portable batteries: 45% by 31 December 2023, 63% by 31 December 2027, 73% by 31 December 2030.
column5: The increase in collection targets may have a positive impact on the target of reaching energy neutrality in the wastewater treatment sector, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Producers of LMT batteries or producer responsibility organisations, shall attain, and maintain durably, at least the following collection targets of waste LMT batteries: 51% by 31 December 2028, 61% by 31 December 2031.
column5: The increase in collection targets may have a negative impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the EU ETS, as it may lead to increased energy consumption and emissions.

column2: Recycled content in industrial batteries, electric vehicle batteries, LMT batteries and SLI batteries: Cobalt: 16% by 2031 (26% by 2036), Lead: 85% (85%), Nickel: 6% (12%), Lithium 6% (15%)
column5: The increase in recycled content may have a positive impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the LULUCF sector, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: All batteries incorporated in market products shall be readily removable and replaceable by the end-user at any time during the lifetime (except some derogations)
column5: The development of removable and replaceable batteries may have a positive impact on the target of upgrading national targets, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recycling efficiency: No later than 31 December 2025 - 75% by average weight of lead-acid batteries, - 80% by average weight of nickel-cadmium batteries, - 50% by average weight of other waste batteries
column3: No later than 31 December 2030 - 80% by average weight of lead-acid batteries
column6: The increase in recycling efficiency may have a positive impact on the target of achieving an EU net greenhouse gas removal, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recycling efficiency: No later than 31 December 2025 - 65% by average weight of lithium-based batteries
column3: No later than 31 December 2030 - 70% by average weight of lithium-based batteries
column6: The increase in recycling efficiency may have a negative impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the EU ETS, as it may lead to increased energy consumption and emissions.

column2: All recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recovery of materials: No later than 31 December 2027 - 90% for cobalt, copper, lead, nickel
column3: No later than 31 December 2031 - 95% for cobalt, copper, lead, nickel
column4: No later than 31 December 2027 - 50% for lithium
column5: No later than 31 December 2031 - 80% for lithium
column8: The increase in recovery of materials may have a positive impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the LULUCF sector, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: All recycling shall achieve at least the following targets for recovery of materials: No later than 31 December 2027 - 50% for lithium
column3: No later than 31 December 2031 - 80% for lithium
column6: The increase in recovery of materials may have a negative impact on the target of reducing buildings' greenhouse gas emissions, as it may lead to increased energy consumption and emissions.

column2: Reduce the generation of food waste in processing and manufacturing by 10% in comparison to the amount generated in 2020
column5: The reduction of food waste may have a positive impact on the target of reducing methane emissions, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Reduce the generation of food waste per capita, jointly in retail and other distribution of food, in restaurants and food services and in households, by 30 % in comparison to the amount generated in 2020
column5: The reduction of food waste may have a positive impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: nan
column5: The development of new technologies may have a negative impact on the target of achieving a climate-resilient society status, as it may lead to increased costs and reduced competitiveness.

column2: Making all packaging recyclable
column5: The development of recyclable packaging may have a positive impact on the target of implementing the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: The plastic part in packaging shall contain the following minimum percentage of recycled content recovered from post-consumer plastic waste, per unit of packaging: From 1 January 2030 (i) 30% for contact sensitive packaging made from polyethylene terephthalate (PET) as major component, (ii) 10% for contact sensitive made from plastic materials other than PET, except single use plastic bottles, (iii) 30% for single use plastic beverage bottles, (iv) 35% for other plastic packaging
column3: From 1 January 2040 (v) 50% for contact sensitive plastic packaging, except single use plastic beverage bottles, (vi) 65% for single use plastic beverage bottles, (vii) 65% for other plastic packaging
column6: The increase in recycled content may have a positive impact on the target of recasting EU legislation, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Member States shall take measures to achieve a sustained reduction in the consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags on their territory. A sustained reduction is achieved if the annual consumption does not exceed 40 lightweight plastic carrier bags per person, or the equivalent target in weight, by 31 December 2025, and subsequently by 31 December in each year thereafter
column5: The reduction in consumption of lightweight plastic carrier bags may have a negative impact on the target of reducing methane emissions, as it may lead to increased costs and reduced competitiveness.

column2: Reduce packaging waste by 5% per Member State per capita compared to 2018 by 2030, 10% by 2035 and 15% by 2040
column5: The reduction of packaging waste may have a positive impact on the target of reaching energy neutrality in the wastewater treatment sector, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Recycling or preparing for re-use 65% of all packaging waste by 2025, 70% by 2030
column5: The increase in recycling or preparation for re-use may have a positive impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the EU ETS, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Recycling of plastic in packaging: 55%
column5: The increase in recycling of plastic may have a negative impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the LULUCF sector, as it may lead to increased energy consumption and emissions.

column2: Recycling of wood in packaging: 30%
column5: The increase in recycling of wood may have a positive impact on the target of upgrading national targets, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Recycling of ferrous metals in packaging: 80%
column5: The increase in recycling of ferrous metals may have a positive impact on the target of achieving an EU net greenhouse gas removal, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Recycling of aluminium in packaging: 60%
column5: The increase in recycling of aluminium may have a negative impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the EU ETS, as it may lead to increased energy consumption and emissions.

column2: Recycling of glass in packaging: 75%
column5: The increase in recycling of glass may have a positive impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the LULUCF sector, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Recycling of paper and cardboard in packaging: 85%
column5: The increase in recycling of paper and cardboard may have a positive impact on the target of reducing buildings' greenhouse gas emissions, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: nan
column5: The development of new technologies may have a negative impact on the target of reducing methane emissions, as it may lead to increased costs and reduced competitiveness.

column2: From 2025, beverage bottles listed in Part F of the Annex which are manufactured from polyethylene terephthalate as the major component (‘PET bottles’) contain at least 25 % recycled plastic, calculated as an average for all PET bottles placed on the market on the territory of that Member State
column5: The increase in recycled content may have a positive impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Member States shall meet the target of 77% by weight for the separate collection for recycling of waste single-use plastic beverage bottles by 2025 and 90% by 2029
column5: The increase in separate collection may have a negative impact on the target of achieving a climate-resilient society status, as it may lead to increased costs and reduced competitiveness.

column2: The minimum collection rate to be achieved annually shall be 65 % of the average weight of EEE placed on the market in the three preceding years in the Member State concerned, or alternatively 85 % of WEEE generated on the territory of that Member State.
column5: The increase in collection rate may have a positive impact on the target of implementing the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: From 15 August 2018, the recovery targets for the WEEE falling within the following categories of Annex III shall be: - 85% for Category 1 (temperature exchange equipment) or Category 4 (large equipment with any external dimension more than 50 cm) - 80% for Category 2 (e.g., screens and monitors) - 75% for Category 5 (small equipment with no external dimension more than 50 cm) or 6 (Small IT and telecommunication equipment with no external dimension more than 50 cm)
column5: The increase in recovery targets may have a positive impact on the target of recasting EU legislation, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: From 15 August 2018, the preparation for re-use targets for the WEEE falling within the following categories of Annex III shall be: - 80% for Category 1 or Category 4 - 70% for Category 2 - 55% for Category 5 or Category 6
column5: The increase in preparation for re-use targets may have a negative impact on the target of reducing methane emissions, as it may lead to increased costs and reduced competitiveness.

column2: From 15 August 2018, the recycling targets for the WEEE falling within the following categories of Annex III shall be: - 0% for Category 1 or Category 4 - 70% for Category 2 - 55% for Category 5 or Category 6
column5: The increase in recycling targets may have a positive impact on the target of reaching energy neutrality in the wastewater treatment sector, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: By 2025, the preparing for re-use and recycling of municipal waste shall be increased to a minimum of 55% by weight (60% by 2030, 65% by 2035)
column5: The increase in preparing for re-use and recycling may have a positive impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the EU ETS, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: Member States should aim to achieve an indicative Union-wide food waste reduction target of 30 % by 2025 and 50 % by 2030
column5: The reduction of food waste may have a negative impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the LULUCF sector, as it may lead to increased energy consumption and emissions.

column2: Hazardous household waste will have to be collected separately by 2022, bio-waste by 2023 and textiles by 2025
column5: The separate collection of hazardous household waste may have a positive impact on the target of upgrading national targets, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: nan
column5: The development of new technologies may have a negative impact on the target of achieving an EU net greenhouse gas removal, as it may lead to increased costs and reduced competitiveness.

column2: nan
column5: The development of new technologies may have a positive impact on the target of reducing buildings' greenhouse gas emissions, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: nan
column5: The development of new technologies may have a negative impact on the target of reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the EU ETS, as it may lead to increased energy consumption and emissions.

column2: nan
column5: The development of new technologies may have a positive impact on the target of reducing methane emissions, as it promotes sustainable practices and reduces waste.

column2: nan
column5: The development of new technologies may have a negative impact on the target of reducing methane emissions, as it may lead to increased costs and reduced competitiveness.
